children.alt: Predictive performance (confusion matrix) of the model trained on the BCW dataset to predict diagnosis. The model was trained on the whole dataset with nested cross-validation.

children.value: Predictive performance (confusion matrix) of the model trained on the BCW dataset to predict diagnosis. The model was trained on the whole dataset with nested cross-validation.

children.alt: Learning curve (top) and power curve (bottom) of the model trained on the BCW dataset to predict diagnosis. The maximum sample size (i.e. the whole dataset) was considered as the “sample size budget”. X-axis: n_{act}; y-axis (learning curve): Accuracy as a measure of predictive performance; y-axis (power curve): statistical power of the remaining sample to confirm the model’s validity.

children.value: Learning curve (top) and power curve (bottom) of the model trained on the BCW dataset to predict diagnosis. The maximum sample size (i.e. the whole dataset) was considered as the “sample size budget”. X-axis:

children.html: nactn_{act}nact​

children.value: ; y-axis (learning curve): Accuracy as a measure of predictive performance; y-axis (power curve): statistical power of the remaining sample to confirm the model’s validity.

children.alt: Predictive performance of the model trained on gray matter probability images from the IXI dataset to predict age. The model was trained on the whole dataset with nested cross-validation. X-axis: true age, y-axis: predicted age.

children.value: Predictive performance of the model trained on gray matter probability images from the IXI dataset to predict age. The model was trained on the whole dataset with nested cross-validation. X-axis: true age, y-axis: predicted age.

children.alt: Learning curve (red) and power curve (blue) of the model trained on gray matter probability images from the IXI dataset to predict age. The maximum sample size (i.e. the whole dataset) was considered as the “sample size budget”. X-axis: n_{act}; y-axis (learning curve): Pearson’s correlation as a measure of predictive performance; y-axis (power curve): statistical power of the remaining sample to confirm the model’s validity.

children.value: Learning curve (red) and power curve (blue) of the model trained on gray matter probability images from the IXI dataset to predict age. The maximum sample size (i.e. the whole dataset) was considered as the “sample size budget”. X-axis:

children.html: nactn_{act}nact​

children.value: ; y-axis (learning curve): Pearson’s correlation as a measure of predictive performance; y-axis (power curve): statistical power of the remaining sample to confirm the model’s validity.

children.alt: Predictive performance of the model trained on resting state functional connectivity data from the HCP dataset to predict fluid intelligence (PMAT24_A_CR). The model was trained on the whole dataset with nested cross-validation. X-axis: true age, y-axis: predicted age.

children.value: Predictive performance of the model trained on resting state functional connectivity data from the HCP dataset to predict fluid intelligence (PMAT24_A_CR). The model was trained on the whole dataset with nested cross-validation. X-axis: true age, y-axis: predicted age.

children.alt: Learning curve (red) and power curve (blue) of the model trained on resting state functional connectivity data from the HCP dataset to predict fluid intelligence (PMAT24_A_CR). The maximum sample size (i.e. the whole dataset) was considered as the “sample size budget”. X-axis: n_{act}; y-axis (learning curve): Pearson’s correlation as a measure of predictive performance; y-axis (power curve): statistical power of the remaining sample to confirm the model’s validity.

Manuscripts, commentaries, and editorials on the topic of brain-behavior associations and their reproducibility, related to
Multivariate BWAS can be replicable with moderate sample sizes
Monica D. Rosenberg and Emily S. Finn
How to establish robust brain–behavior relationships without thousands of individuals
The challenge of BWAS: Unknown Unknowns in Feature Space and Variance
Brain-behavior correlations: Two paths toward reliability
Reproducible brain-wide association studies do not necessarily require thousands of individuals
Reproducible between-person brain-behavior associations do not always require thousands of individuals
The Burden of Reliability: How Measurement Noise Limits Brain-Behaviour Predictions
Precision behavioral phenotyping as a strategy for uncovering the biological correlates of psychopathology
Precision behavioral phenotyping as a strategy for uncovering the biological correlates of psychopathology
Behavioral phenotypes, stochastic processes, entropy, evolution, and individual variability: Toward a unified field theory for neurodevelopment and psychopathology
Lost in transformation: fMRI power is diminished by unknown variability in methods and people
On the statistics of brain/behavior associations
Putting behaviour back into brain–behaviour correlation analyses
Brain-behavior associations depend heavily on user-defined criteria
Commentary on ‘Reproducible brain-wide association studies require thousands of individuals’
Scanning reproducible brain-wide associations: sample size is all you need?
Cross-validation for the estimation of effect size generalizability in mass-univariate brain-wide association studies
Study design features that improve effect sizes in cross-sectional and longitudinal brain-wide association studies
Reports of the death of brain-behavior associations have been greatly exaggerated
The challenges and prospects of brain-based prediction of behaviour
